intro.description: This cheat sheet is going to work through creating preparing the ownship sensor data ready for production of TMA tracks.

item.title: Load datafiles
item.description: We're using new datafiles for this step, so double-click on nonsuch.rep in the Navigator to load ownship track (and select DR mode when asked). Perform a Fit to Window once loaded to have a look at the track. Next, drag in sensor.dsf.

item.title: Make sensor data visible
item.description: To keep the plot tidy, sensor data is not shown by default when loaded. Expand Track:NONSUCH in the Layer Manager, then select Sensor:Sensor_A (52 items). Once the Sensor A sensor data is selected, click on the tick icon in the toolbar at top of the Layer Manager view, to make the sensor data visible.

item.title: Set array offset
item.description: As you'll see, the sensor data is ambiguous as produced by a towed array. Currently Debrief is plotting the sensor cuts against the attack datum of the platform, but we need to apply an offset for this sensor (451m in this case). So, select Sensor:SENSOR_A in the Layer Manager, then open the Properties Window (the click to perform button below will also open it). In the Properties Window you'll see the SensorOffset attribute, enter -451 metres in this field, click on the Plot, and you'll see the bearings jump to reflect the change.

item.title: Reduce data density
item.description: Whilst it isn't necessary for this exercise, Debrief does allow you to reduce the density of the sensor data. If you right-click on Sensor:SENSOR_A, then navigate down into the SENSOR_A sub-menu you will see a Visible Frequency option. Using one of these options will pass through sensor data and hide sensor observations between the specified frequency. The sensor cuts remain available, and can be made visible again by selecting a smaller visible frequency.
